Maybe there is truth to it. It's based on some assassination. But in that play, there's of course a character. I mean, it's the character from the title. It's Macbeth. That guy. But the other character that everybody remembers from Macbeth is of course Lady Macbeth, right? She's the definition, the literary epitome of a sneaky, beautiful female monster lurking in the shadows behind her husband and behind that smile is something more than devious, something evil and bloodthirsty and corrupting instead of being the woman who props up her man and gets the best stuff out of him. She's the woman who drags him down into the pit and uses him and manipulates him to satisfy her ambitions. And if you do, that makes about as much sense as naming your kid Jezebel. But in 1 Kings 21, there's this legendary enemy of the good guys of the Bible in the age of the kings. This is back in the age of the divided kingdoms. You got the kingdom of Israel up north and then you got the kingdom of Judah down south and up north. You got this horrible king named Ahab who's a lot like Xerxes. He's bloodthirsty sometimes, but also weak and manipulatable. I mean, this is our familial inheritance. This is our whole fortune. Our whole future is wrapped up in this. I can't do it. They have a bunch of rhymes about toil and trouble and bubbles and cauldrons and things like that. And they tell him that these crazy things are going to happen and you're going to become king.
